intro: Phyllanthus sellowianus, commonly known as the Brazilian pear or Sellow's spurge, is a shrub native to South America. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves that are often lobed or serrated. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in clusters, followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. It is often found in tropical and subtropical regions, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is cultivated in some parts of the world.
